description: This two-semester second-level writing course aims to guide students to (1) practice basic academic writing convention, (2) sharpen analytical essay writing skills, (3) enhance essay coherence and cohesion, and (4) develop a clear writing style. The course will familiarize students with proper academic language and convention to compose five-paragraph short essays on the following five modes of writing: argumentation, definition, causal analysis, process analysis, and comparison and contrast. In addition to the different analytical modes of writing, the course will introduce students to organizing and editing strategies to fine-tune their essay writing. On the one hand, students will learn how to apply principles of coherence and cohesion in their writing to maintain consistent claims and to offer logical transitions at the levels of ideas, sentences, and paragraphs. On the other hand, students will learn how to develop a clear writing style by avoiding common sentence errors and improving concision and specificity in word choice and sentence formation.
goals: To help students student develop their ability to express themselves in writing essays in English
To help students write various kinds of essays in a well-organized manner
syllabus:
Intermediate Composition I (Fall 2020)

Syllabus

Instructor: Chingshun J. Sheu 許景順 ([cjsheu@ntnu.edu.tw](mailto:cjsheu@ntnu.edu.tw)).

Class meetings: Fridays 1320-1510.

Objectives: Students will learn how to write argumentative and narrative essays that incorporate emotional, informational, and reader-response writing strategies. They will also learn to appreciate the use of these strategies in essays by their peers and published writers.

Grading:           66% Essays

20% Participation

14% Weekly journals

Essays: Students will write two essays, respectively argumentative and narrative. Missed deadlines cannot be made up. _If there is plagiarism in drafts, the instructor will provide no feedback. Plagiarism in final submissions will result in an essay grade of 0 (zero)._

Participation: After each peer review session, students will evaluate the level of participation of their group members. These evaluations will not be directly translated into the participation grade but will rather serve as indicators of participation.

Weekly journal: Students will submit one journal entry each for at least 14 weeks. A journal entry will be graded based solely on whether it has been submitted. Submitting more than 14 journal entries may result in extra credit. No late submissions. _Plagiarized and repeated journal entries will not be counted_.
